title.rendered: Where Does the 3D Printing Ecosystem Stand Today?

content.rendered:
How much do you think the average person knows about 3D printing? The answer might surprise you. The public’s understanding of 3D printing has grown as the industry continues to earn major news coverage and 3D printing is also gaining popularity with the world’s largest brands as well.  

But while this exposure increases the general public’s awareness of 3D printing, it leaves them longing to learn more about how 3D printing really works. For that information they turn to the web and resources such as this site and TechCrunch where Andreas Bastian gives a great breakdown of how the 3D printing ecosystem is working today. 

Key takeaways from Bastian’s piece are two-fold.

1. Today’s 3D printing creations are designed for old manufacturing processes.

The bulk of the products, trinkets and fun designs being created in the 3D printing market are most likely carryovers that were originally  designed to be manufacture via other technologies. Projects created solely for 3D printing exist in the market as well and while they are not the norm yet, expect their number to grow as the technology continues to develop and gain awareness.

2. Hardware and software must work together.

To make this technology efficient the software has to improve to and better align with the existing hardware. This will allow applications to correct a mistakes in real time while also allowing users to check the status remote and share the status of the job with other users. Software is what makes our world go and that will absolutely apply here as well.

3D printing is still a very new technology, especially as it pertains to the mass public. But as the industry grows, so too will their awareness and that’s an exciting prospect for 3D printers everywhere. Because innovation always appears a little more quickly when it is driven by demand.
